posts.name: Layton
posts.cooked: What do I need to open on the sysid application to start tuning are motors

If you’re using a pre-made swerve library (I know CTRE phoenix swerve does it), look into if it has built-in sysid logging capabilities.

If you’re using phoenix swerve code, you need to set a sysid routine in the code (all the code for it is already there), manually run it, then pull and convert the hoot file in phoenix tuner. The converted wpilog file can then be opened in sysid and the motors being tested can have their parameters selected.

If you’re using something else like YAGSL , it appears it may have some sysid code built in that you could figure out how to use.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Do you understand what SysId does, and can you tune your mechanism without it if necessary?

If the answer to the above is “no,” you shouldn’t be using SysId yet.  Focus on manual tuning.

posts.cooked: So on our krakens we can change the values in the tuner but the same values are in the code as well to me it means we do both but I know some times motors can be weird

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: I prefer setting configuration in code when possible to modifying it in the tuner.  Like you said, it works most of the time, but the few times it gets desynced can be very frustrating.  Compile+deploy is pretty fast these days, anyhow.
